Review Deciphering engineering principle of three-phase interface for advanced gas-involved electrochemical reactions Yanzheng He a 1 Sisi Liu a 1 Mengfan Wang a 1 Qiyang Cheng a Tao Qian b c ⁎ Chenglin Yan a c ⁎ a Collaborative Innovation Center of Suzhou Nano Science and Technology, College of Energy, Soochow University, Suzhou 215006, Jiangsu, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Suzhou Nano Science and Technology College of Energy Soochow University Suzhou 215006 Jiangsu China Collaborative Innovation Center of Suzhou Nano Science and Technology, College of Energy, Soochow University, Suzhou 215006, Jiangsu, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nantong University, Nantong 226019, Jiangsu, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nantong University Nantong 226019 Jiangsu China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nantong University, Nantong 226019, Jiangsu, China c Light Industry Institute of Electrochemical Power Sources, Suzhou 215600, Jiangsu, China Light Industry Institute of Electrochemical Power Sources Suzhou 215600 Jiangsu China Light Industry Institute of Electrochemical Power Sources, Suzhou 215600, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract The engineering principles of the three-phase interface in the gas-involved electrochemical reaction are reviewed. Three design strategies related to active sites, mass diffusion, and electron transfer are summarized. As an alternative to conventional energy conversion and storage reactions, gas-involved electrochemical reactions, including the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), have become an emerging research direction and have gained increasing attention due to their advantages of environmental friendliness and sustainability. Various studies have been designed to accelerate sluggish kinetics but with limited results. Most of them promote the reaction by modulating the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, ignoring the synergistic effect of the reaction as a whole. Due to the introduction of gas, traditional liquid–solid two-phase reactions are no longer applicable to future research. Since gas-involved electrochemical reactions mostly occur at the junctions of gaseous reactants, liquid electrolytes and solid catalysts, the focus of future research on reaction kinetics should gradually shift to three-phase reaction interfaces. In this review, we briefly introduce the formation and constraints of the three-phase interface and propose three criteria to judge its merit, namely, the active site, mass diffusion and electron mass transfer. Subsequently, a series of modulation methods and relevant works are discussed in detail from the three improvement directions of ‘exposing more active sites, promoting mass diffusion and accelerating electron transfer’. Definitively, we provide farsighted insights into the understanding and research of three-phase interfaces in the future and point out the possible development direction of future regulatory methods, hoping that this review can broaden the future applications of the three-phase interface, including but not limited to gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Keywords Three-phase reaction Surface reactions Mass diffusion Electron transfer Gas-involved electrochemical reactions 1 Introduction With the development of the social economy, the excessive consumption of fossil fuels has led to a worldwide energy crisis and serious environmental pollution [1–4]. After decades of research and development, some reliable solutions have been proposed through several electrochemical reactions, including the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which are driven by electricity generated from renewable energy sources [5–12]. Several potential electrocatalysts have been excavated to satisfy the smooth processes of gas-involved electrochemical reactions, and diversified strategies have been put forward to obtain further optimizations [13–16]. However, their actual performance is less than satisfactory. The main reason can be attributed to the complexity of the reaction system, which is located in a multiphasic environment [1,17,18]. Considering the integrality and cooperativity of the entirety, excellent overall performance can only be achieved with the existence of three-phase electrochemical interfaces instead of the single regulation of individual factors [19–23]. As gases, liquids, and solids are the three typical states of matter in nature, the intersections of two or more different states have been discovered in gas-involved electrochemical reactions and have attracted much attention from researchers [23,24]. These multiphase interfaces have many interesting physical and chemical properties and are an essential branch of interface science [25]. Among them, gas–solid and liquid–solid two-phase interfaces have been extensively studied in CO2RR, NRR and HER, and numerous relevant studies have been carried out [26,27]. Nevertheless, it is impossible to ensure the existence of only two interactions in the actual catalytic reaction process. In reality, there exist not only liquid electrolytes but also gas reactants and solid catalysts in various gas-involved electrocatalytic reactions [28]. The interaction of gas molecules and liquid molecules/ions makes interfacial diffusion and mass transfer processes potential rate-determining steps, which should be involved in the study of multiphase interfaces [29,30]. Unfortunately, traditional two-phase catalysis research has been unable to cope with these conditions due to their ignorance of the severe problems caused by the presence of gas and liquid, such as catalyst wetting, bubble covering and active site obstruction, and cannot be employed to accurately evaluate actual situations [31–33]. Therefore, based on the above problems, the study of the gas–liquid–solid three-phase interface has gradually become a unique research direction for multiphase electrochemical reactions. As summarized in previous reports, gas-involved electrochemical reactions mainly occur at the interface of solid catalysts, liquid electrolytes, and gas reactants, where electrons and molecules have full access to the active sites and functions, often referred to as three-phase reaction interfaces [34]. The existence of such a region is indispensable for gas-involved electrochemical reactions, and there are still some crucial constraints on the actual performance [35]. Three judgment criteria are given in this review, and several judicious optimization works accomplished currently in these three criteria were detailed for further investigation (Fig. 1 ). First, the quantity and activity of active sites that function have been recognized as measures of reaction performance, which can be employed to evaluate the capacity of adsorption and desorption behavior of the catalyst for reactants, intermediates and products [36,37]. Second, the concentration of reactants, intermediates, and even products at the interface, which depend on mass diffusion, can significantly determine the reaction rates for gas-involved electrochemical reactions [38,39]. Furthermore, electron transfer is also an important factor and is mainly determined by the intrinsic properties of the catalyst. The inferior conductivity of some catalysts is also a significant reason why electron transport is hindered [40,41]. In summary, the overall activity of gas-involved electrochemical reactions will benefit from multivariate optimization of the above three aspects. Eventually, based on an in-depth comprehension of the structure–activity relationship and multicomponent electrochemical characteristics, we further raise some of our own observations and perspectives and confidently expect that this review will shed light on future investigation of gas-involved electrochemical reactions regarding interface science. 2 Facilitation of surface reaction Typically, most electrochemical reduction reactions take place on the surface of catalysts. It is well known that the active phase on the catalyst surface is an essential indicator of catalytic ability [42,43]. For gas-involved electrochemical reactions, exposing the active sites at the three-phase interface so reactants, products, electrons and electrolytes can pass smoothly over the surface is essential to utilizing the active sites fully and obtaining excellent performance [44]. However, various catalyst designs did not adequately consider this issue in the past. Currently, an increasing number of researchers are focusing on facilitating the surface reaction to realize excellent electrochemical performance [45,46]. To facilitate the surface reactions at three-phase interfaces, the regulations of active actives are essential. As has been proposed by Jaramillo et al., increasing the number of active sites and improving the intrinsic activity of single sites should be two general strategies [47]. As for some catalysts with extremely low activity catalytic sites, simply increasing the number of active sites could not ensure the smooth progress of the three-phase interface reactions. Correspondingly, for some materials with high catalytic active sites, most of the active sites are unable to participate in the three-phase interface reaction, which also cannot meet the requirements of promoting gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Thus, the above two strategies are not mutually exclusive and can ideally be addressed simultaneously, leading to the greatest improvements in activity. A great deal of work has been done on this issue to address the problem from two perspectives which are described in detail in the next two subsections [48,49]. 2.1 Increased number of active sites Typically, the surface reaction should be a complex problem, and the active sites will greatly affect the reaction efficiency of three-phase interfaces. Most active sites are often confined within the bulk phase, with only a tiny fraction distributed on the catalysts’ surface [50]. In this case, factors within the reaction system cannot reach the internal active sites, resulting in the “death” of these active sites. Although there exists three-phase interface, the dead active sites will cause a limited surface reaction at the interfaces. This inaccessibility prevents the activity of the catalyst from being fully functional [51–53]. Generally speaking, to effectively regulate the active sites and three-phase interfaces, the wetting state should be primarily understood. The wetting state can be roughly divided into three categories, including Cassie state, Cassie-Wenzel coexistent state, and Wenzel state [23]. The Cassie state shows that the surface of the electrode is dominated by the gas phase, and only contact with a little liquid phase to construct insufficient three-phase interfaces. The Wenzel state shows that the whole electrode is almost immersed in the liquid phase and the gaseous reactants can only reach the catalyst surface through the slow liquid phase diffusion process, which is adverse for the gas-involved electrochemical reactions. The above two states cannot achieve perfect three-phase interface construction around electrodes, hindering the gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Under the above premise, Jiang’s group designed superhydrophobic electrodes with different underwater wetting states from silicon-based substrate. They pointed out that the Cassie-Wenzel coexistence state was favorable to increasing the number of active sites, in which a rich three-phase interface was formed on the rough surface or pore structure of the catalyst layer, and the active sites were fully exposed to the local environment to realize high efficiency reactions [54]. Thus, increasing the number of active sites should be one of the measures that can improve the reaction efficiency of three-phase interfaces. Based on the above principles, several practical strategies on catalyst design have been proposed. Sun's team prepared a highly uniform mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon material with a cylindrical channel structure using a soft-template method to promote CO2RR and convert CO2 into ethanol at a low potential of –0.56 V versus reference hydrogen electrode (vs RHE), achieving a conversion rate of up to 77% [55]. The pyridine/pyrrole N site at the cylindrical pore structure possessed a high electron density, which facilitated the dimerization of CO* intermediates and was therefore considered the catalytically active site. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) results showed that relative to the inverse mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon material, this ordered mesoporous carbon possessed highly ordered cylindrical and bar-shaped mesoporous macrodomains along and perpendicular to the two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal mesoporous structure, respectively, which allowed sufficient exposure of active sites and improved the overall activity of the catalyst (Fig. 2 a). In addition, as reported by Bao et al., a postsynthetic modification strategy was proposed, which trapped ammonium ferric citrate on the surface of zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanoparticles [56]. After pyrolysis, abundant Fe-N active sites were dispersed on the carbon matrix surface (Fig. 2b). With entirely exposed active catalytic sites at the three-phase interfaces, outstanding selectivity and mass activity were obtained, which were superior to those of most reported noble metal catalysts. Moreover, He’s group designed a free-standing, cross-linked and high-yield carbon membrane, called CoSA/HCNFs, to maximize the exposure of single-atom Co active sites [57]. Such three-dimensional (3D) net-like CoSA/HCNFs nanofibers with a continuous porous structure possess a large electrochemical active surface area, which favors the formation of three-phase interfaces (Fig. 2c). With more exposed single Co active sites, a 92% Faradaic efficiency and a 211 mA cm−2 current density of CO2RR were successfully achieved. Several works with referential significance focusing on increasing the number of active sites have also played an essential role in the field related to NRR [58,59]. As reported by Xin’s group, single Mo atoms anchored on N-doped porous carbon (SA-Mo/NPC) were synthesized by decomposing a hydroxylamine hydrochloric acid precursor containing Mo [60]. Through XAS characterization, Mo-N and Mo-C bonds were observed on carbon supporting materials, indicating a large number of dispersed Mo single atoms, which is conducive to generating high-density atomic-level NRR active sites (Fig. 3 a). With the assistance of these active sites, a high NH3 production rate (34 μg h−1 mg−1) and a Faradaic efficiency (14.6%) were obtained. Moreover, a unique NRR electrocatalyst with single Zn(I) sites supported on hollow porous N-doped carbon nanofibers (Zn1N–C) was reported by Hou’s group [61]. The structural characterizations indicated that atomically dispersed Zn(I) sites served as the active sites, which synergized with surrounding graphitic N sites to promote the NRR process. The BET results further demonstrated that the Zn1N–C nanofibers possessed a high specific surface area of 198 m2 g−1 with a pore diameter of approximately 4 nm, signifying that more active sites were exposed to the three-phase interfaces for superior NRR performance (Fig. 3b). Under this premise, a high NH3 yield rate of ≈ 16.1 µg h−1 mg−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 11.8% in alkaline media were successfully achieved. Furthermore, a novel strategy of regulating the crystalline degree of polymeric metal-free catalysts to improve the NRR process was proposed by Dai’s group [62]. Molecular dynamics and COMSOL Multiphysics simulations revealed that a desirable “quasi-gas–solid” interface formed between N2 and catalysts due to the limitation of H2O molecules in desirable crystal regions, where as many active catalytic sites were exposed as possible. Thus, a high Faradaic efficiency of up to 60.5% with a maximum NH3 production rate of 16.8 µg h−1 mg−1 were achieved in a neutral-buffered seawater electrolyte (Fig. 3c). Such far-sighted research has provided forceful guidance for further catalyst design with sufficient functional active sites. Besides, increasing the number of active sites also plays an obvious role in optimizing the three-phase interface during the conversion of NO to NH3 (NORR). As reported by Chu et al., atomically Fe-doped and S-vacancy-rich MoS2 (Fe1/MoS2− x ) was successfully designed to facilitate the NORR process [63]. With the assistance of vacancy engineering, basal planes can be activated and more active sites of catalyst are exposed. The increased number of active sites effectively optimized the three-phase interfaces, supporting a high NH3 yield of 288.2 μmol h−1 cm−2 with an NH3-Faradaic efficiency of 82.5% at − 0.6 V vs RHE. Increasing the number of active sites is also indispensable for the HER process. Hence, several strategies for exposing more active sites have been developed successfully. MoS2 is an excellent pH general-purpose electrocatalyst for the HER, but its catalytic activity is often inhibited by its limited density of active edge sites [64,65]. To effectively solve this problem, Wilkinson et al. developed two-dimensional MoS2 nanosheets (NSs) with high active site density through a microdomain reaction method [66]. By changing the annealing temperature, the active site density could be readily tailored, and the highest active site density was observed at an annealing temperature of 550 °C (Fig. 4 a). With this excellent catalyst, superior HER performance was achieved with a relatively small Tafel slope of 68 mV dec−1. Moreover, as a transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD), CoSe2 is also a potential HER catalyst, but how the specific structure affects the catalytic activity is still unclear. Feng's team specifically investigated the variations in the CoSe2 structure and active sites by doping phosphorus into CoSe2 [67]. It was found that the introduction of phosphorus changed the structure of CoSe2 from a cubic phase (c-CoSe2) to an orthonormal phase (o-CoSe2|P). In the annealing process of c-CoSe2, phosphorus occupied abundant vacancy defect sites caused by the drop of Se. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation results showed that Co sites possessed a very high affinity and dissociation ability for water molecules, and P sites exhibited a very low ΔG H* value of − 0.08 eV, which was conducive to promoting HER performance (Fig. 4b). The high density, high activity and easily accessible catalytic active sites of this porous material make it one of the most active HER catalysts at present. This strategy guided the subsequent design of two-dimensional ternary transition metal compounds and deepened the researchers' understanding of the active sites of catalysts. 2.2 Improved intrinsic activity of the single site In addition to focusing on the number of active sites, the intrinsic activity of the single site is equally important for the operation of three-phase interface [68]. Generally speaking, three-phase interfaces are mainly constructed at the junction of catalyst, electrolyte, and gaseous reactants, among which, in particular, surface reactions should occur around the active sites on the catalyst surface. As defined by previous generations, active sites refer to groups where chemical reactions can occur and its intrinsic activity is determined by the properties of catalyst [69]. As an important component of the catalyst with good catalysis performance, the intrinsic activity of the catalytic active site should be evaluated by whether it promotes the surface reactions [70,71]. Typically, active sites with high intrinsic activity can realize high reaction rate of three-phase interface reactions. Thus, improving the intrinsic activity of single catalytic site should be a promising direction to optimize the surface reactions, which is beneficial to the operation of efficient three-phase interfaces. Typically, increasing the activity of a single active site requires an emphasis on the design of the catalyst. Defect design, regulation of electronic structure, and doping of highly active atomic sites will all be reliable design strategies. There are numerous studies related to this aspect. He et al. prepared through-hole carbon nanofibers (TCNFs) by embedding Cu/ZIF-8 into polymer nanofibers for efficient and highly stable electrochemical CO2RR [72]. The improved self-supported through-hole structure allows the highly efficient Cu single-atom (CuSA) active sites to replace the embedded metal sites with low activity. The highly active CuSA sites exist in the form of Cu-N4 groups, all of which can participate in the CO2RR reaction. Moreover, compared with that of Ni-N4 sites, Cu-N4 sites exhibited a slightly positive free energy (0.12 eV) for *CO desorption, which effectively inhibited CO evolution (Fig. 5 a). The improved high-quality Cu active sites eventually yielded a superior Faradaic efficiency of 44% and a partial current density of 93 mA cm−2 for methanol as well as a long-term stability of 50 h. Moreover, Li’s group investigated the activity of active sites on nitrogen-coordinated and atomically dispersed iron and cobalt catalysts. Fe- or Co-doped metal–organic framework precursors were adopted with nitrogen-coordinated Fe or Co sites atomically dispersed into carbons (MNC), which contain bulk- and edge-hosted M−N4 coordination [73]. DFT results indicated that edge-hosted M−N2+2−C8 moieties bridging two adjacent armchair-like graphitic layers functioned as the active sites, which were more active than previously proposed bulk-hosted M−N4−C10 moieties embedded compactly in a graphitic layer (Fig. 5b). Notably, Fe was intrinsically more active than Co in M−N4 for the reduction of CO2 to CO. With the assistance of superior Fe-N2+2-C8 active catalytic sites, a higher CO Faradaic efficiency (FE) (93%) was successfully achieved. Similar strategies are also put forward in the NRR process. For example, Chen et al. synthesized nanoporous PdH materials by a two-step method [74]. First, the Pd-Al alloy was chemically unalloyed by HCl etching, and then np-PdH0.43 was obtained by in situ hydrogenation (Fig. 6 a). SEM and TEM confirmed the existence of a nanoporous structure, in which the active sites were mainly distributed and more active. DFT results revealed that the lowest Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of *N2H generation, which should have been the rate-determining step, was found at N2-adsorbed site 2 and site 3 Pd atoms. As these active sites exhibited high activity, the intrinsic activity of np-PdH0.43 was incredibly promoted, resulting in an NH3 yield rate of 20.4 μg h−1 mg−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 43.6%. In addition, as reported by Ju’s group, molybdenum oxide decorated on a rhodium (RhMoO x /C) catalyst was successfully synthesized with an outstanding NH3 yield rate of 57.2 μg h−1 mg−1 at − 0.6 V vs RHE and a high Faradaic efficiency of 22% at − 0.2 V vs RHE in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte [75]. XPS results revealed the existence of Mo oxide and Ru phase active sites, which synergistically improved the catalyst activity. Further DFT results probed the positive effect of promoting the NRR process on the dual active sites of Mo and Rh compared with the pristine Ru electrode. Moreover, the activity of dual catalytic sites could also be enhanced by varying the oxidation states of Mo, further contributing to the enhancement of NH3 production. High-quality active sites are equally important in promoting the HER process. Li et al. self-assembled negatively charged polystyrene nanosphere solutions containing glucose and ammonium thiomolybdate on the surface of polyaniline-modified carbon cloth [65]. They obtained ordered macroporous structures with MoS2 nanocrystals uniformly embedded in carbon nanohybrids by controlling the decomposition rate of the precursors under an inert atmosphere. Highly activated unsaturated S-edge active sites could be generated on MoS2 nanosheets through sodiation/desodiation. DFT showed that these active sites optimized ΔG H* values, which played a leading role in the high catalytic activity of the HER (Fig. 7 a). This strategy provided a new possibility for designing other two-dimensional metal catalysts, effectively improving the electrocatalytic hydrogen production activity. In addition, Lee’s group synthesized a kind of all-in-one MoS2 catalyst, which contained multifunctional active sites for the HER process derived from the 1 T-phase, defects, S vacancies and exposed Mo edges with expanded interlayer spacings (Fig. 7b) [76]. With the full functionality of abundant multifunctional active catalytic sites, the HER process was greatly improved, and an outstanding performance superior to those of all previously reported MoS2-based electrocatalysts was obtained. Moreover, Shui et al. reported an efficient HER catalyst that anchored phosphated IrMo bimetallic clusters on macroporous nitrogen-doped carbon (IrMoP/MNC) [77]. The introduced P and Mo atoms have been demonstrated to regulate the electronic structure of atomically dispersed Ir synergistically, which increased the intrinsic activity of the nearby Ir atoms and significantly enhanced the HER kinetics. 2.3 Summary In summary, numerous strategies exist to facilitate the surface reaction of catalysts through pre- or post-treatment. With the assistance of these strategies, many formerly inert catalysts have been rejuvenated and have become splendid active catalysts that are currently ahead of their time in various fields. These exposed active sites fully exert their catalytic activity, which is necessary for an excellent three-phase interfacial reaction. Moreover, advanced theoretical calculations and in situ characterizations allow for better design of catalysts and detection of realistic active site distribution. With the aid of theoretical calculations and corresponding experiments, catalyst structures that can expose more catalytic active sites can be simulated, allowing researchers to perform more targeted experimental validation. We believe that innovative design principles and synergistic strategies can be explored with the guidance of theoretical calculations and simulations, aiming at constructing an all-surface-area structure that can expose high-density active sites for sufficient utilization. 3 Promotion of mass diffusion An efficient mass transfer process is more beneficial for the construction of an efficient three-phase electrocatalytic interface, which can significantly enhance the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst [78]. For gas-involved electrochemical reaction, the construction and optimization of mass transfer channels are critical to ensure the fluidity of multiple reactants and products [79]. An excellent gas transfer channel is required to ensure the timely and smooth adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates and products during the reaction processes [80]. However, such a tremendous mass transfer channel is challenging to build successfully because of several limitations in practical applications [81]. What follows is an overview of current constraints and responses from two aspects. 3.1 Abundant supply of reactants One of the most challenging obstacles is the difficulty of contact of some gas molecules with the catalyst due to their extremely low solubility [82,83]. For instance, in the NRR process, nitrogen seems to be almost insoluble in water at room temperature and pressure. Although high pressure can significantly increase the solubility of N2, it violates our original intention of performing electrocatalytic NRR and cannot be applied to practical situations [84,85]. Gas diffusion electrode (GDE) have been proposed to improve the gas diffusion kinetics, which is frequently exploited in fuel cells, metal-air batteries and CO2RR, and it does seem to play a particular role in optimizing the accessibility of gaseous reactants [86–88]. However, the traditional widely produced GDEs have been found to have some problems in practical applications. With prolonged electrolyte contact, the hydrophobicity of waterproof coatings such as PTFE decreases, causing the original gas transport channels to be gradually submerged by the electrolyte, slowing the gas diffusion kinetics and resulting in a loss of reaction efficiency, which is not worth the cost [89,90]. In order to solve this problem, a number of strategies have been proposed in terms of optimizing the electrode, electrolyte, and reactor. For electrodes, hydrophobicity and directional diffusion channels are required, and modification of catalyst surface should be the most commonly used strategy. In addition, some novel solvation effects, such as salt-out effect, can be used to promote mass transfer of gaseous reactants within the electrolyte, effectively increasing the local concentration of reactants around the catalyst. Moreover, it is also a basic strategy to design an efficient three-phase interfacial membrane reactor to take full advantage of the GDEs and directly feed gas reactants to the catalyst surface, which could also promote the mass transfer of reactants. Several outstanding strategies have been proposed in the CO2RR process to achieve improved performance. As reported by Feng et al., a hydrophobic electrode design that can construct stable three-phase interfaces and enhance CO2 electrolysis by promoting mass transfer around catalytic sites was proposed [91]. They first proved that a hydrophobic substrate for the electrode could facilitate the CO2RR performance in a conventional H-cell. Subsequently, by dispersing hydrophobic PTFE nanoparticles inside the catalyst layer, a novel hydrophobic catalyst microenvironment was designed, where the hydrophobic PTFE could repel liquid electrolyte and gather gaseous reactants around catalytic sites (Fig. 8 a). Attributed to the decrease in the diffusion layer thickness, a balanced gas/liquid microenvironment formed and played an essential role in enhancing the mass transport and electrolysis kinetics, facilitating the activity and Faradaic efficiency of the CO2RR. Notably, remarkable performance was achieved with commercial Cu nanoparticles as the catalyst, which meant that such a concept could be a general approach to improve the mass transfer of other gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Furthermore, they improved this strategy and applied it to the electrocatalysis of CO2 to formate on Bi-based catalysts [92]. A partial current density of 677 mA cm−2 and 35% single-pass conversion at –0.7 V vs RHE were obtained with the aid of a moderate hydrophobicity. Consistent with the preceding research, this report provided strong evidence for the superior facilitation of the CO2RR performance again due to the control of the three-phase interfaces, which mediated the transport of reaction species and improved reaction kinetics (Fig. 8b). Besides, Cassie-Wenzel coexistence wetting state introduced above have also been demonstrated to be the best guideline of GDEs design that can maintain three-phase interfaces at high current densities, which can continuously supply CO2 to active sites. For a proof of concept using a typical metal/C electrode, the interfacial CO2 mass diffusion coefficient was 0.27 cm s−1 when the current density was greater than 100 mA cm−2, which was sufficient to maintain 80% of the initial interfacial CO2 concentration as reported by Zhang’s group [93]. It provided valuable new insights for the rational design of non-diffusion controlled CO2RR electrodes and interface engineering. Despite the chemical modification of the three-phase interfaces, paying more attention to the design of the catalyst structure can also help accelerate mass diffusion. It is acknowledged that a highly porous structure possesses adequate transfer channels for the diffusion of gaseous reactants and electrolytes [94,95]. The structure of the pore is critical for the effective mass transfer of reactants to the surface. Deng et al. investigated the relationship between the porous structure and CO2RR performance [96]. The experimental results demonstrated that the geometric current density of C2H4 on Cu particles (Cu-Ps)/carbon paper with a porous layer (CP-MPL) was twice that of Cu-Ps/CP-25% when the PTFE content was the same (Fig. 8c). Furthermore, scanning electron microscopy images indicated that the Cu-Ps/CP-MPL electrode exhibited a granular microporous structure with a pore size of approximately 100 nm. Thus, the microporous structure of Cu-Ps/CP-MPL was proven to effectively increase the diffusion of CO2 at the gas/liquid/solid interface compared with pure Cu-CP. Similarly, some other strategies that regulate electrode/electrolyte (E/E) interfaces also play driving roles in promoting mass diffusion. For example, Mougel et al. brought the ‘plastron effect’ into reality and trapped CO2 at the E/E interface with a 1-octadecanethiol-treated Cu dendrite electrode [97]. A superior three-phase interface was effectively formed with an abundant supply of reactants, and the Faradaic efficiency reached 86% with almost 74% C2 products. Moreover, the optimization of self-supported electrode permeability can also be a promising strategy to effectively promote the mass transfer process and increase the concentration of reactants at the three-phase interface. Owing to the efficient Sn/Cu catalysts for CO2 reduction to CO, Battaglia’s group proposed a self-supported nanofiber gas diffusion electrode with Sn and Cu coated through electrospinning technology [98]. Compared with Sn/Cu-nylon electrode, due to the higher intrinsic gas permeability of Sn/Cu-PVDF electrode, the mass transfer of CO2 was effectively promoted. Thus, the partial current density of CO was significantly increased, and the partial current density of H2 was greatly inhibited, indicating a critical impact of the self-supported electrode for maintaining high CO2 to CO conversion rates and suppressing the competing hydrogen evolution reaction. Although there are some problems with traditional GDE, it is undeniable that it plays an important role in promoting gas mass diffusion at the three-phase interface. Several novel strategies that focus on the optimization of GDE are also meaningful. The highly tunable system parameters within GDE-based flow electrolyzers should be one of the advantages. Tan et al. pointed out that should consider from three perspectives of catalyst layer structure, feed CO2 concentration, and feed flow to design GDEs for adjustment of the local CO2 concentration [99]. Besides, the understanding of the gas diffusion layer (GDL) are equally important for the mass diffusion. Sargent’ group focused on this issue and proposed a ionomer bulk heterojunction (CIBH) architecture, which optimized the mass transfer inside the electrode [100]. Benefiting from a metal and a superfine ionomer layer with hydrophobic and hydrophilic functionalities, the mass diffusion has increased from the order of nanometers to the order of microns, significantly facilitating the CO2RR process. Furthermore, they successfully designed fluoropolymer GDLs through 3D printing technology [101]. The tunable microporosity and structure enabled the increase of the diffusive path length and residence time of locally produced CO near the catalyst, which was favorable for the production of C2+ species. Moreover, previous GDE only allows catalysts in series, which hardly manage the mass diffusion and hinder the production of C2+ products. Wu et al. designed segmented GDEs (s-GDEs) to prolong CO residence time in the subsequent C2+-selective segment, increasing the conversion rate [102]. Such a novel GDE design opened up the application idea of GDE and better regulated the mass diffusion during the reaction process. In addition to the optimization of conventional GDEs, Koper’s group highlighted a new electrode configuration for efficient CO2RR [103]. Owing to the defect-rich porous structure and extraordinary favorable mass transport conditions, the Cu hollow fibre can realize a better performance. This work provided guidance for the discovery of new gas diffusers and large-scale production for commercial application. In particular, the stability and regeneration of the three-phase interface in GDE is another issue worth considering, especially for the mass diffusion of reactants. Janáky’s group focused on this issue and pointed out that the formation of alkaline metal bicarbonate and mixed bicarbonate precipitated plaques inside the cathode GDE of cells using alkaline anodic solution largely reduced the three-phase interfaces, preventing CO2 gas from reaching the catalyst surface [104]. They developed an operando activation method to design scalable water-fed electrolyser cells. The performance of such cells over long periods (more than 200 hours) was comparable to that of cells using alkaline electrolytes (jCO of 420 ± 50 mA cm−2). The repeatable activation process can reduce the continuous desorption and leaching of alkali cations from the cathode catalyst layer during operation, maintaining the continuous stability of the three-phase interface, and timely promoting the mass transfer of CO2. In addition, MEA-based electrolytic cells have demonstrated the longest durability. All in all, the high stability and continuity of the three-phase interface plays an important role in improving the mass transfer at the three-phase interface. Combining the advantages of various electrolytic cells including flow, MEA and solid oxide electrolyzers, optimizing the interface design will be an important means to maintain the stability of the three-phase interface and promote the mass diffusion of reactants [105]. Now that CO is one of the products of CO2RR, CO reduction reaction (CORR) is more controllable. Due to the inherent stability of CO under alkaline conditions, there is no need to consider the problem of carbonation compared with the CO2RR process. Compared with CO2RR, CORR is superior particularly for production of C2+ at high current densities. The applications of GDE in CORR to facilitate the mass diffusion is more widespread. Xiang’s group developed two distinctive types of GDE configurations including a flow-through configuration and a flow-by configuration [106]. It has been proved that the flow-through GDE exhibited a better mass diffusion process, significantly achieved efficient CO transport, obtained a great three-phase interface, and greatly improved the reaction rate of CORR catalysts. Subsequently, Sargent et al. have done a lot of work on GDE to promote the mass diffusion and realize efficient CORR [107–110]. A novel work focused on the optimization of gas delivery inside GDEs was worth to be introduced [111]. Kanan et al. proposed an interdigitated flow field in GDE to maximize the flux of CO through carbon-based GDE to the Cu catalyst layer. Three different mass diffusion configurations were examined and they pointed out that high single-pass conversion and high Faradaic efficiency can be concurrently realized with a suitable regulation of CO diffusion. In short, CORR selectivity is greatly affected by GDE. The concentration of local reactants can be effectively regulated by optimizing the flow rate and velocity of CO during the reaction process by adjusting the GDE morphology/nanostructure, so as to achieve the reduction of CO into different C2+ products, improving the selectivity and conversion rate. The principles of design for promoting mass diffusion of reactants regard of NRR have not changed. Analogously, the catalyst structure can be regulated to meet the requirement of faster mass diffusion. For instance, a rational design of a catalyst composed of atomic iron sites anchored on a N,O-doped porous carbon (FeSA-NO-C) matrix with an inverse opal structure was proposed by Hou et al. [112]. The linear dependence of the current was determined to judge the diffusion-controlled process, and the results indicated that compared with NO-C and FeSA-NO-C-900 without SiO2, a larger mass diffusion coefficient was obtained by FeSA-NO-C-900 (Fig. 9 a). Such an observation implied that the unique inverse opal structure contributed to the fast mass transfer of reactants during the NRR process, guaranteeing the smooth functioning of the three-phase interfaces. With this improvement, a high Faradaic efficiency of 11.8% and an NH3 yield rate of 31.9 μg h−1 mg−1 were successfully achieved. In addition, Yang’s group constructed a functional 3D porous MXene-based composite heterojunction aerogel through a divalent metal ion-induced assembly and sulfidation process (Fig. 9b) [113]. The resultant 3D porous composite heterojunctions possess a large specific surface area, hierarchically porous channels and interfacial interaction between metal sulfide NPs and S-doped conductive MXene nanosheets, effectively enabling rapid mass diffusion of N2 to the three-phase interfaces and receiving an NH3 yield rate and a Faradaic efficiency of 12.4 µg h−1 mg−1 cat and 27.05% at the lower potential of − 0.15 V vs RHE. In addition to the regulation of catalyst structure, some other strategies inspired by GDEs have also made great contributions to promoting nitrogen diffusion around three-phase interfaces [114]. As reported by Ling’s group, a hydrophobic layer of zeolitic imidazolate framework-71 (ZIF) was introduced to the surface of the electrocatalyst [115]. Such a ZIF layer exhibited superhydrophobicity that can protect the encapsulated electrocatalytically active surfaces from the poison of water molecules (Fig. 9c). Moreover, the superior gas sorptivity of the metal–organic framework (MOF) gathered N2 around the catalyst surface, which significantly increased the concentration of the reactant and promoted gas diffusion kinetics. Thus, this molecular enrichment effect has been demonstrated to promote interfacial mass diffusion and improve NRR performance effectively and could be easily extended to other materials to establish a versatile “build-on” strategy. Wang and coworkers regulated the catalyst surface from another perspective [116]. They obtained an aerophilic-hydrophobic heterostructure by coating a porous framework consisting of hydrophobic PTFE on the catalyst surface (Au-PTFE/TS). The bubble capture experiments revealed that the bubble contact angle on the Au-PTFE/TS surface was approximately 88°, while that of the Au/TS surface was almost 111° (Fig. 9d). This phenomenon implied that the Au-PTFE/TS surface has a robust interaction with N2 bubbles, and the introduction of the PTFE framework transformed the catalyst from aerophobic to aerophilic. Therefore, when Au-PTFE/TS was immersed in the electrolyte, N2 would reach the active sites on the catalyst surface more easily due to the presence of porous frameworks, and the reactant mass diffusion was greatly enhanced, resulting in an excellent NRR performance. Our group also have achieved great success in this aspect [117–119], and the best work of all is the proton-filtering covalent organic frameworks, which were first put forward to realize superior nitrogen penetration flux and consequently achieve a superior NRR performance with an NH3 yield rate of 287.2 μg h−1 mg−1 and Faradaic efficiency 54.5%. In addition, a work previously reported by our group focused on the permeability of electrodes, and we designed a micro/nano electrode that can be widely used to facilitate gas mass diffusion [120]. Once N2 bubbles touch the electrode surface, they will first be broken into nanoscale by the nanostructure and diffused smoothly along the micron channel to the active site for efficient reaction. An NH3 yield rate of 78.1 μg h−1 mg−1 and a corresponding Faradaic efficiency of 85.9% was successfully achieved. Such a work provided valuable insights for the subsequent design and optimization of self-supported gas diffusion electrodes with high permeability. 3.2 Timely evacuation of products As gas-involved electrochemical reactions are thermodynamic equilibrium reactions, the effective desorption and diffusion of products also play important roles in promoting the reaction kinetics [121]. Abundant products accumulated on the surface of three-phase interfaces will lead to poisoning of the active site and inhibit the forward reaction. In addition, for reactions that generate gaseous products, the accumulation of bubbles on the electrode surface hinders the transfer of electrolytes to the active site, which leads to a significant Ohmic drop and is a primary reason for the degradation of catalytic performance [122]. Typically, the air–water-solid three-phase contact line (TPCL) is continuous for flat surfaces, and bubbles adhere solidly to it [123]. According to previous studies, some hierarchical micro- and nanostructures can effectively break the TPCL into a discontinuous state, where the electrolyte would flow into the void, and the contact between the bubbles and the electrocatalytic interface was reduced, thus facilitating the release of the bubbles [124,125]. Thus, designing and optimizing the structural morphology seems to be an excellent strategy to promote timely desorption of products. Since these acute problems still exist in constructing an effective mass transfer channel, an increasing number of researchers, regardless of the field, now focus on these factors and have proposed numerous favorable strategies [126–128]. With the help of these proposals, products can be promptly evacuated, which effectively alleviates the poisoning effect of the active site and promotes the reaction balance. With the regulation, the three-phase interface has been optimized, leading to a continuous improvement in catalytic performance. Innovative strategies have been proposed to facilitate the desorption and diffusion of products. First, excellent gas–liquid-solid three-phase interfaces were engineered by Sun’s group [129]. After modification by polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), the contact angles of H2, C2H4 and CO decreased from > 140° to 66.7°, 86.8° and 104.3°, which demonstrated a holding effect for H2 and C2H4 and a positive effect for CO (Fig. 10 a). A similar trend was also found for liquid products such as HCOOH, ethanol and n-propanol, proving the affinity of the products around the three-phase interface. In addition, as reported by Liu’s group, atomically dispersed magnesium atoms embedded in graphitized C3N4 (Mg-C3N4) were developed for the CO2RR process [130]. The CO TPD results revealed that no CO desorption peak occurred on Mg-C3N4 compared with the obvious CO desorption peaks on Fe-C3N4 and Co-C3N4 (Fig. 10b). Such a phenomenon indicated that CO could easily desorb from Mg sites, facilitating the timely evacuation of products, which further promoted CO2RR performance with a large current density (−300 mA cm−2) under a FECO ≥ 90% over ≈ 15 000 s. Similar research is also prevalent in the NRR field. As described by Guo’s group, O-vacancy-rich MoO3- x anchored on Ti3C2T x -MXene (MoO3- x /MXene) was designed as a highly active and selective NRR electrocatalyst [131]. MD simulations were carried out to study the dynamic process of NH3 desorption on different catalysts. The results revealed that there were fewer NH3 molecules gathered around MoO3– x /MXene. RDF also indicated that MoO3– x /MXene had a weaker NH3-catalyst interaction than MoO3– x . In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was further performed to investigate the NH3 behavior on various catalysts. A new NH3 peak (≈ 1215 cm−1) appeared on MoO3- x but was absent on MoO3- x /MXene, indicating that the produced NH3 could easily desorb from the surface of MoO3- x /MXene (Fig. 10c). Hence, NH3 was confirmed to complete the evacuation process easily, facilitating the progress of NRR with an NH3 yield rate of 95.8 µg h−1 mg−1 (−0.4 V vs RHE) and a Faradaic efficiency of 22.3% (−0.3 V vs RHE). Noticeable strategies for achieving timely evacuation of products in the three-phase reactions were also proposed for better HER performance [132]. The regulation of catalyst structure inside GDEs can help better promote mass diffusion [133]. For example, Ag-incorporated Ni-Co-P hollow nanobricks (HNBs) were fabricated through a template-assisted strategy by Lou’s group (Fig. 11 a) [134]. The hollow structure in nanobricks could be observed through SEM and TEM, which promoted the diffusion of H2 during the HER process, resulting in a superior HER performance with a lower Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1. In addition, through electrodeposition, self-supported nickel phosphide (Ni2P) nanosheets were loaded on 3D graphene/nickel foam (G/NF) by Cai et al. (Fig. 11b) [135]. The heterostructures anchored on macroscopic conductive substrates could effectively facilitate the release of the H2 product, and a current density of 10 mA cm−2 was obtained under a low overpotential of 75 mV. Despite the catalyst structure, another challenging obstacle that hinders product evacuation in the HER process is the adhesion of generated H2 bubbles, which will create dead areas and cause a vast Ohmic drop, as mentioned above. As early as 2014, Jiang’s group found that nanostructured MoS2 films on conductive substrates exhibited a faster HER, a current increase and a more stable working state than their flat counterparts, which was realized by the alleviation of the adhesion of as-formed gas bubbles on the surface [136]. Subsequently, they focused on this phenomenon and thoroughly investigated the reason behind it. Pt electrodes with three different surface morphologies, including flat, nanosphere and pine-shaped nanoarray electrodes, were prepared for HER [137]. The experimental results showed that the adhesive force of bubbles was lowest for the Pt nanoarray film electrode, followed by the Pt nanosphere electrode and Pt flat plate electrode, which meant that the Pt nanoarray film electrode exhibited superaerophobic properties. Moreover, optical images revealed that the generated bubbles left the Pt nanoarray electrode surface before they expanded, which was hardly observed on the surface of the other two comparison samples (Fig. 11c). Thus, a lower bubble adhesive force effectively decreased the size of the as-formed bubbles and accelerated the release of gas bubbles, which further facilitated the gas diffusion kinetics and promoted the increasing rate and stability of the current density for HER. Moreover, in addition to the diverse interface design strategies mentioned above, the mass transfer can also be effectively regulated from the perspective of reactor and electrolyte to facilitate the gas-involved electrochemical reactions. For instance, Liu et al. proposed a concept of mesoporous carbon bowl (MCB) nanoreactor to enhance mass diffusion in gas-involved electrochemical reactions, taking the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) to produce H2O2 as a model [138]. The Finite-element simulations (FES) results indicated that the MCB-350 bowl with the largest window size has a very large vortex, which led to the pressure difference between the inside and outside of the bowl and a faster through-holes flow velocity, significantly speeding up the mass transfer process. Such a novel report focused on the reactor provides a fresh understanding of the structure–property relations for nanoreactor engineering and is favorable for inspiring the design of nanoscale reactors and macroscale devices for better mass diffusion process. On the other hand, from the point of view of electrolyte, the utilization of solvation effect to promote the mass transfer process near the three-phase interface is also a promising measure [139,140]. A previous work of our group focused on the salt-out effect in high electrolyte concentration. The hydration shell formed by solute ions greatly promoted the nitrogen flux on the catalyst surface and realized the continuous supply of reactants on three-phase interface [119]. 3.3 Summary In other words, to effectively promote the mass diffusion of gas-involved electrochemical three-phase reactions, nothing more than enriching the supply of reactants and realizing timely evacuation of products is needed. Once the reactants are sufficient, mass transfer around active sites will be improved, which maximizes the utilization of active sites and effectively facilitates the reactions. Meanwhile, with timely evacuation of products, the poisoned active site can restore the activity and promote the thermodynamic equilibrium of the reaction forward. Designing structures and alleviating the bubble adhesive force of as-formed bubbles can be effective solutions. Theoretical calculations and in situ characterizations have also played indispensable roles in the formulation of these strategies. The mass diffusion at the three-phase interface should be investigated more deeply through the in-depth combination of multiscale theoretical calculations, simulations and experiments. We believe that more novel strategies will be proposed and implemented in the future with consistent investigation. 4 Acceleration of electron transfer As the core of electrochemical reactions, electron transfer directly determines the rate of the reaction and should be an essential direction in the investigation of the functionalization of three phase interfaces. In general, the conductivity of the catalyst will directly affect the electron transfer throughout the reaction process and further determine the overall reaction rate [141]. Weak electrical conductivity inhibits the smooth transfer of electrons to catalysts, which prevents active sites from functioning thoroughly and leads to underutilization [142,143]. Many works have been put forward to enhance the conductivity of catalysts to promote effective electron transfer at the three-phase interface and improve catalytic activity [144–146]. 4.1 Efficient combination with a conductive component Typically, metal compounds exhibit high activity for electrochemistry theoretically, while their intrinsic electrical conductivity is too poor for catalytic reactions [147,148]. Meanwhile, it is well known that carbon materials, such as graphene, porous carbon, and carbon nanotubes are generally extremely conductive, but these materials have little catalytic activity, which is unfavorable for gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Under this premise, it is not difficult to find that the hybridization of metal compounds with high catalytic activity and carbon materials with high conductivity will be the main strategy to effectively boost electron transfer and optimize the three-phase interface reactions [149]. Several novel strategies have been implemented around this central idea. CO2RR is a multielectron reaction that should pay more attention to the process of electron transfer [150]. As reported by Li et al., a 3D highly stable porphyrin-based MOF of PCN-222(Fe) was introduced into heterogeneous catalysis through the simple dip-coating method (Fig. 12 a) [151]. Such an active molecular catalyst immobilized in an MOF scaffold possessed a fast electron transfer rate and presented excellent catalytic activity for the CO2RR to CO with a maximum Faradaic efficiency of 91% and a low overpotential of 494 mV (where j = 1.2 mA cm−2). In addition, Wang’s group fixed tetraphenylporphyrin cobalt (PCo) onto graphene and demonstrated that the existence of a relay molecule could obviously facilitate interfacial electron transfer [152]. Through systematic analysis of their structure, benzene rings of diphenyl sulfide were found to exhibit strong face-to-face stacking with graphene, being an efficient medium to facilitate interfacial electron transfer. With this improvement, a higher differential pulse voltammogram (DPV) current was obtained, signaling an evident facilitation of electron transfer (Fig. 12b). Moreover, a series of new polyoxometalate (POM)-based manganese-carbonyl (MnL) composite electrocatalysts with remarkable CO2RR activity and selectivity were reported by Li et al. [153]. Several studies, including photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL), transient photovoltage (TPV) experiments, electrochemical experiment and DFT calculations, have proven that POMs functioned as electronic regulators during the CO2RR process, which can purposefully regulate electron transfer from POM to MnL units, greatly increasing the CO2RR selectivity (Fig. 12c). In addition, He’s group developed a novel Sn-based material as catalyst. Electrospinning technique was utilized to create a composite of a bimetallic Sn-Co oxide/carbon matrix with a hollow nanotube structure (SnCo-HNT) [154]. Theoretical calculations were carried out to prove that the fusing of Sn/Co oxides on the carbon matrix accelerated electron transfer at the atomic level, leading to electron deficiency of Sn centers and reversible variation between Co2+ and Co3+ centers. Such a synergistic effect of the Sn/Co composition facilitated the electron affinity of the catalyst surface and was conducive to the adsorption and stabilization of key intermediates, eventually contributing to the superior catalytic activity in the CO2RR process with a 91.2% faradaic efficiency and a 241.3 mA cm−2 partial current density for C1 products. Several innovative works have also been carried out to promote electron transfer during the NRR process. First, theoretical studies were carried out to investigate the specific effect of electron transfer at the three-phase interfaces during the NRR process. Gao’s group probed the bonding mechanism of Fe-transition metal dimers on substrates from the perspectives of orbital hybridization and electron transfer [155]. Eight models of double-atom Fe catalysts supported on graphene-based substrates (Fe-TMDA/GS, TM = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) were established for theoretical investigation (Fig. 13 a). They pointed out that electron transfer should be the main factor affecting nitrogen adsorption, and the electron transfer between N2 and the graphene surface was facilitated by inducing the second metal atom, enhancing the NRR catalytic activity. Such a theoretical investigation provided powerful evidence for the importance of electron transfer during the NRR process, which guided the rational design of catalysts to accelerate electron transfer at the three-phase interfaces. Under this premise, Yu’s group developed a 3D amorphous BiNi alloy [156]. DFT calculations revealed that Ni substitution can modulate the electronic configuration of Bi. Further XPS results demonstrated that electrons tended to transfer from Ni to Bi, achieving a modulation of the electronic configuration, which compensated for the sluggish electron transfer between Bi atoms and enhanced the overall electrical conductivity (Fig. 13b). Thus, the 3D interconnected conductive pathways in porous alloys were proven to serve as an outstanding conductive network to accelerate electron transfer and further achieve outstanding electrochemical performance with an NH3 yield rate of 17.5 μg h−1 mg−1 and a Faradaic efficiency of 13.8%. Several other regulations have also been made to accelerate electron transfer. For instance, Ling and coworkers provided a strategy using the zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF) to modify the Pt/Au electrocatalyst d-band structure electronically [157]. The introduction of ZIF can induce electron-deficient sites on the catalyst. Meanwhile, electron density transfer occurred between ZIF and the Pt catalyst, which lowered the d-band of Pt/Au to weaken metal–H interactions while facilitating metal–N2 interactions. Such a facilitation was achieved through the optimization of the electron transfer process and further improved the catalytic activity of Pt/Au@ZIF (Fig. 13c). Compared with Pt/Au, an excellent Faradaic efficiency of > 44% with an NH3 yield rate of > 161 μg–1h mg−1 was obtained on Pt/Au@ZIF. In addition, as reported by Xie et al., a strongly coupled CoS2/NS-G (N- and S-doped reduced graphene) catalyst was designed [158]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analysis indicated that the charge-transfer resistance of CoS2/NS-G was smaller than that of CoS/NS-G and NS-G. Thus, strong bridging bonds were demonstrated to successfully form at the interface between CoS2 nanoparticles and graphene sheets, accelerating the electron transfer process (Fig. 13d). As a consequence, the hybrids exhibited outstanding NRR activity with a high NH3 Faradaic efficiency of 25.9% under ambient conditions. In addition, the acceleration of electron transfer at the three-phase interface through novel catalyst design was also achieved in the NORR process. Chu’s group synthesized a SnS2− x catalyst enriched with S-vacancy defects through a defect engineering strategy [159]. The electronic structures of catalyst were examined by DFT calculations. The projected density of state (PDOS) combined with the EIS results indicated that a new defect level appears at the conduction band minimum of SnS2− x , reducing the band gap and enhancing the conductivity. Benefiting from the unique property, the electron transfer of three-phase interfaces was obviously accelerated and the catalytic NORR kinetics were highly boosted. Moreover, the same group further designed a highly active and durable NORR catalyst with atomically dispersing Co atoms on MoS2 (Co1/MoS2) [160]. The introduction of Co was beneficial to the regulation of the electron structure of MoS2 and effectively facilitated the electron transfer between the catalyst and three-phase interfaces with narrowed band gap and reduced work function, achieving an NH3 yield of 217.6 μmol h−1 cm−2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 87.7% at − 0.5 V vs RHE. The investigation of HER also requires paying attention to the process of electron transfer. A vapor-phase transformation method was reported by Hou’s group to construct well-aligned nickel-based MOF (Ni-MOF) nanoarrays on electrochemical exfoliated graphite (EG) foil and further obtain Ni-MOF/Ni2P@EG through phosphorization treatment [161]. Due to the strong coupling effect of the constructed interfaces in this hybrid, electrons could be effectively transferred from Ni2P to Ni-MOF (Fig. 14 a). With this unique three-phase interfacial property, the adsorption of water molecules was promoted, which further accelerated the water dissociation step and achieved a superior HER performance with low overpotentials of 132 mV at 10 mA cm−2 as well as a small Tafel slope of 59 mV dec−1 in alkaline media. In addition, compared with their crystalline counterparts, amorphous phases have been demonstrated to be more favorable for electron-transfer kinetics due to their short-range order values. Under this premise, Lee et al. designed RhCo alloy nanotubes through the reduction of single-phase Co2RhO4 nanotubes [162]. The XPS results revealed that electrons transferred from Co to Rh and that there was an alloying process between Rh and Co, which greatly accelerated the electron transfer (Fig. 14b). As a result, a superior HER performance with a low overpotential at − 10 mA cm−2 (−22 mV) and a small Tafel slope (−24.1 mV dec−1) was obtained. Besides, Cheng et al designed a hollow oxygen deficiency-enriched NiFe2O4 catalyst, which was synthesized by pyrolytic FeNi bimetallic MOF [163]. The rGO provided abundant defects during carbonization which would act as nucleation sites for FeNi particles. The deposited carbon effectively connected N/rGO and hollow oxygen deficiency-enriched NiFe2O4 together, giving full play to the advantages of N/rGO in fast electron transfer, thereby improving its catalytic activity with a low overpotential of 157 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER in 1 M KOH. In addition, HER catalysts with high electron transfer under high current density have also been studied in detail. Gao’s group designed NiFe2O4 nanoparticles/NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheet heterostructure array on Ni foam [164]. Owing to the intrinsic advantages and strong coupling effects of NiFe2O4 nanoparticles and NiFe LDH nanosheets, the synthesized catalyst exhibited outstanding electronic conductivity and high catalytic reactivity. Larger current densities of 500 and 750 mA cm−2 were obtained at overpotentials of 297 and 314 mV, indicating a perfect HER performance. 4.2 Rational design of the self-supported electrode In addition to enhancing conductivity from the perspective of catalyst, designing strategies from the perspective of electrode preparation can also boost the electron transfer. Generally speaking, the conventional electrodes can sometimes suffer from a range of problems, such as the coffee-ring effect, dead volumes, blockage of the active sites caused by the blinder, catalyst peeling, etc., especially for drop-coated electrodes [21]. Moreover, the binder added during the configuration of the catalyst slurry has inferior conductivity, which likewise increases the overall resistance and thus hinders electron transfer [165]. To address these problems, designing binder-free self-supported electrodes seems to be a better strategy. Several novel measures have been proposed to optimize electrode by depositing or in situ growing catalysts directly on conductive substrates. Part of the current work related to the CO2RR has successfully addressed this issue [166,167]. Wang’s group successfully deposited planar CoII-2,3-naphthalocyanine@S/N/O heteroatom-doped graphene (NapCo@SNG) on a planar glassy carbon electrode (GCE) [168]. The results of cyclic voltammetry (CV) proved that with the support of SNG, molecular Co sites could realize redox, and the electron transfer between the molecular Co sites and SNG was greatly accelerated, as proven by differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) measurements (Fig. 15 a). Under this condition, a superior Faradaic efficiency of up to 97% of the CO2RR to CO was obtained. Moreover, as reported by Ozin et al., an all-carbon, electroactive, nitrogen-doped nanoporous-carbon/carbon-nanotube composite membrane (HNCM/CNT) was manufactured (Fig. 15b) [169]. Such a membrane could function as a binder-free gas diffusion electrode for the efficient reduction of CO2 to formic acid. The brand-new carbon located on the CNT surface possessed abundant defects and short-range ordered micropores. Under this premise, the heteroatoms were aligned at the CNT surface through templating interactions, thereby achieving a high electron transfer efficiency via charge transfer interactions, which in turn modified the catalytic activity. With the assistance of efficient electron transfer, a Faradaic efficiency of 81% for the production of formate was obtained. Similar works were also put forward to optimize electron transfer during the NRR process. As reported by Wang’s group, a micelle-assisted replacement method was proposed to synthesize mesoporous Au3Rh film in situ on Ni foam (mAu3Rh/NF) [170]. Such a self-supported electrode avoids the negative effects of the binder and exhibits a bimetallic mesoporous structure, which greatly improves the NRR performance. The XPS results revealed that there was a positive offset in the Au 4f orbital compared with the mAu film and a negative offset in the Rh 3d orbital compared with the mRh NPs, indicating a strong electronic effect between Au and Rh (Fig. 16 a). Such a positive electronic effect could greatly accelerate the electron transfer, further contributing to a remarkable NRR performance with an NH3 yield rate of 26.29 μg h−1 mg−1 cat and a high Faradaic efficiency of 23.84% for NRR in 0.1 M Na2SO4 at −0.1 V vs RHE. In addition, Zheng et al. also reported an excellent self-supported electrode and achieved outstanding NRR performance [171]. A surfactant-free hydrothermal reaction coupled with high-temperature calcination was employed to synthesize porous Fe2O3 nanorods on carbon cloth (p-Fe2O3/CC) (Fig. 16b). In this binder-free self-supported electrode, electron transfer was greatly facilitated, and a high NH3 yield rate of 6.78 μg h−1 cm−2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 7.69% were obtained at − 0.4 V vs RHE in 0.1 M Na2SO4. Moreover, Hu’s group designed a boron and sulfur co-doped mesoporous Rh film on Ni foam (B, S-mRh/NF) [172]. As expressed by the XPS results, a negative shift occurred on the B, S-mRh film (3d 5/2 of 311.6 eV and 3d 3/2 of 306.9 eV) compared with the binding energy of pure Rh (3d 5/2 of 312.1 eV and 3d 3/2 of 307.3 eV), revealing electron transfer between nonmetal elements and Rh (Fig. 16c). Owing to the binder-free characteristics and multicomponent alloy, a high NH3 yield rate of 11.88 μg h−1 cm−2 at − 0.1 V vs RHE and a Faradaic efficiency of 38.42% at − 0.05 V vs RHE were achieved in a neutral electrolyte. All of the above strategies provided reliable support for the rational design of binder-free self-supported NRR catalysts. Some remarkable strategies that focus on electrode design also play important roles in promoting HER performance. For instance, Duan’s group proposed a flexible 3D film that combined porous C3N4 nanolayers with nitrogen-doped graphene sheets [173]. Such a self-support configuration electrode could be directly used for HER without any other modifications (Fig. 17 a). Due to the existence of a 3D conductive graphene network, the electrical conductivity was capitally improved, which meant that the electron transfer process was effectively facilitated. Attributed to the strong synergistic effect originating from the 3D conductive graphene network, an excellent HER performance with a small overpotential of 80 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a Tafel slope of 49.1 mV·dec−1 and a remarkable durability were obtained on the PCN@N-graphene film. Moreover, by electrodepositing NiCoFe ternary layered double hydroxides (LDHs) onto 3D conductive scaffolds, Wei et al. fabricated a monolithic-structured electrode [174]. The EIS results showed that the ternary LDHs exhibited lower charge transfer resistance and a faster electron transfer process than the binary LDHs, which was mainly attributed to the doping of Co (Fig. 17b). The formation of CoOOH caused by the oxidation of Co(OH)2 accelerated electron transfer at the Ni(OH)2 electrode, which effectively improved the overall electrochemical activity. The integral composite electrodes were equipped with a more conductive electronic structure, which provided an obvious synergistic effect of multiple transition metals. Interestingly, the synergistic effect diminished when the Co doping was too high, which led to an increase in charge transfer resistance and inhibited the performance of the electrocatalyst. Besides, Shi’s group successfully deposited highly reactive element La on Ni form to prepare hierarchical honeycomb LaNi5 alloy (ho-LaNi5/NF) electrode, which was more facile and universal than the traditional nickel foam preparation technology [175]. Combined with polarization measurements, the Nyquist plots revealed that ho-LaNi5/NF possessed the smallest charge-transfer resistances, exhibiting the fastest electron transfer rate and the best HER activity. Thus, the self-supported electrode presented excellent electrical coupling and conductivity, providing a 3D self-supported heterostructure for better HER performance. 4.3 Summary To summarize, electron transfer is also essential in studying electrocatalysis at three-phase interfaces. Either introducing a superior conducting component into the catalyst or designing a self-support electrode can accelerate electron transfer, which facilitates the reaction performance. Fundamentally, strategies always start from the perspective of electronic structure design. An excellent electronic structure of the catalyst layer can accelerate electron transport across the three-phase reaction interface. Therefore, it is vital to gain an in-depth understanding of the electronic structure and the actual active sites of various electrocatalysts, which can be achieved by combining experimental and theoretical investigations. In the short run, we believe that the acceleration of electron transfer should be one of the most important criteria to judge the performance of a three-phase interface. Under this guidance, more remarkable strategies to improve the three-phase interface are anticipated in the near future. 5 Conclusions Interface science is a mature research direction that plays an important role in gas-involved electrochemical reactions. After decades of investigation and verification, several factors have been proven to obviously influence the construction and function of the three-phase interface. With the assistance of an electrochemical interface with an outstanding architecture, the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts can be thoroughly activated, and a superior reaction performance can be achieved. In this spotlight, we established three criteria that can help better design electrochemical interfaces from facilitation of surface reactions and promotion of mass diffusion to acceleration of electron transfer. Under this premise, some relevant representative works that look for novel strategies to meet the above three requirements have been summarized in detail. However, considering that interface science is a complex research discipline, there still exist numerous mysteries of three-phase interfaces waiting for understanding and probing. To better comprehend and more effectively apply the three-phase reaction interface to reality, we put forward some unique opinions and point out future development directions as follows. 5.1 Comprehensive understanding of multiphase reactions through theoretical calculations and simulations. As three-phase reactions should occur in complex systems, theoretical calculations and simulations can be the best approach to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the practical principles. It is undeniable that conventional off-line experiments and semiempirical formula simulations have made great contributions to understanding the fundamentals of three-phase interfaces. However, only statistical data can be achieved through several classic experiments, such as the Washburn method, contact angle and adhesive force, which may provide limited information or even cause misunderstandings [176,177]. Thus, accurately evaluating three-phase interfaces remains a huge task. To address these issues, several promising theoretical models have been proposed to visualize the process of construction and function of three-phase interfaces, providing a more direct understanding of the reactions occurring around the interfaces [178,179]. For instance, the wetting state discussed above can be a crucial factor in constructing three-phase interfaces. The Cassie-Wenzel coexistent state has been demonstrated to be able to form abundant three-phase interfaces inside the catalyst layer, which could realize an optimized mass diffusion process. Thus, intelligently designing and flexibly applying advanced theoretical models for investigation will provide more accurate and useful information for further three-phase interface construction. 5.2 Deeper investigation of multiphase reactions through in situ characterizations Despite theoretical calculations can enhance our understanding of the three-phase interface, some specific assumptions are not supported by experiments. In situ characterizations, which operate under actual reaction conditions, should be powerful means to observe the formation and change of the three-phase interface in real time with different presentations. As reported by Zhang’s group, one kind of confocal laser scanning microscopy with high resolution and environmental compatibility was designed to observe the electrolyte [180]. With the assistance of water-soluble fluorescein, the liquid boundary with green fluorescence can be easily identified once exposed to a confocal excitation light source. Through their different fluorescence decay behaviors along the z-axis, the wetting states can be faultlessly investigated, which can help design better electrochemical interfaces. Such a technique can theoretically achieve submicron-level resolution, providing more accurate information for the investigation of interfaces. Moreover, the same group proposed in situ fluorescence electrochemical spectroscopy to evaluate the mass diffusion property of different interfaces [93]. The direct quantitative analysis of mass diffusion between different interfaces is of great importance in designing efficient three-phase interfaces that are favorable for gas-involved electrochemical reactions. With the assistance of advanced in situ characterizations, the three-phase interface becomes increasingly visible so that researchers can better regulate the parameters to achieve a better three-phase reaction performance. Under the guidance of in situ characterizations, three-phase interfaces can be deeply investigated for thorough comprehension, which is of great significance to better constructing structures. 5.3 Multivariate design and regulation of reaction interfaces Now that the current strategies for designing and regulating three-phase interfaces have achieved decent success, there is still a wide scope for further improvement. The regulation of three-phase interfaces should be considered multifariously, in addition to the perspective of catalysts, electrolytes and gaseous reactants are equally essential. Discovering brand new design strategies and synergistic principles is of great importance. For instance, an all-surface-area structure will shine in future three-phase interface applications, which possess a high density of active sites and can be fully exposed for sufficient utilization. In addition, as the indispensable carrier of gas and protons, the electrolyte will also affect the three-phase interfaces. Typically, compared with aqueous electrolytes, the proton supply in nonaqueous electrolytes is scarce, and an extremely high overpotential reaction is required to proceed. Actually, the solubility of gaseous reactants in some unique non-aqueous electrolytes is superior to that of aqueous electrolytes. For instance, the solubility of nitrogen in tetrahydrofuran is nearly 40 times that of water at room temperature and pressure [117]. Besides, the highly fluorinated ionic liquids (ILs) were also proved to exhibit a high N2 solubility [181]. Moreover, CO2 has also been demonstrated to possess higher solubility relative to water in some non-aqueous electrolytes, including acetonitrile, methanol, and some ionic liquids [182–185]. Therefore, the gas solubility can be greatly improved through the optimization of electrolyte, which will significantly promote the mass diffusion in the gas-involved electrochemical reactions. We propose that how to compromise and combine the advantages and disadvantages of both kinds will be a hot optimization topic in the future. Moreover, the quality of the electrode is equally important in strengthening the function of three-phase interfaces. Smart and efficient electrodes should attach importance to mass diffusion as well as stability and selectivity. With the assistance of some advanced nanotechnologies, such as electrospinning and 3D printing, which emphasize structural design, more progressive self-supported electrodes can be brought into reality. Finally, device design should also be given identical attention. An excellent electrolyzer should favor rational mass diffusion and electron transfer in the whole reaction system. For example, the proposed membrane reactor, which typically utilizes GDEs, exhibiting an outstanding performance. Different from conventional single chamber cells or H-type cells, with the aid of a superior hydrophobic layer, balances between gas and liquid can be generated, and three-phase reaction interfaces can be effectively formed.
