However, research focused on devices is still rare and requires substantial effort. In short, the efficient design and regulation of the three-phase interface requires a holistic consideration, including catalyst, electrolyte, device design, etc. Only the overall coordination of reaction systems can synergistically promote the full functionalization of the three-phase reaction interfaces. Overall, electrocatalytic performances can be expected to be greatly facilitated with superior three-phase interfaces. Persistent attention and efforts should be afforded to explore more effective strategies that can help design and regulate reaction interfaces. The issues mentioned above are anticipated to better perceive the in-depth structure–function relationship between interfaces and reaction systems and guide proposals of more effective and feasible strategies to promote the commercial applications of various gas-involved electrochemical reactions. Nowadays, the concept of three-phase interfaces has been widely applied in various gas-involved electrochemical reactions, such as CO2RR, NRR, and HER mentioned above. We are faithful that such interfacial science research will light the way for not only CO2RR, NRR, and HER, but also some other electrochemical reactions, including the chlorine evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction and so on. For example, Zhang’s group successfully realized acetylene reduction to ethylene, overcoming the restriction of acetylene interfacial mass transfer in alkali electrolyte, and achieved considerable conversion and selectivity [186]. Of course, with the deepening of research and broadening of the field, the practical application of three-phase interface is no longer limited to electrocatalysis, but also involves some other research fields. Jiang's group studied in detail the enhanced photocatalytic reactions at the air–liquid–solid joint interfaces [187]. The three-phase interfaces have been demonstrated to be able to rapidly and continuously deliver electron scavenger oxygen. Under high intensity light, the photogenerated electron-hole pairs can also be separated effectively, which significantly improves the kinetics, reaction rate and photostability of the photocatalyst, and the reaction rate is nearly 10 times higher than that of the two-phase system. Besides, Zhang et al also developed a fluid three-phase system that is favorable for the H2O2 production and achieved excellent results [188]. It is anticipated that under the guidance of this review, researchers can get a comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the three-phase interface and extend its application scope to other fields involving interface research. Chenglin Yan is a professor and dean of the College of Energy at Soochow University in Suzhou, China. He received his PhD from Dalian University of Technology in 2008. coredata.dc:description: As an alternative to conventional energy conversion and storage reactions, gas-involved electrochemical reactions, including the carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), have become an emerging research direction and have gained increasing attention due to their advantages of environmental friendliness and sustainability. Various studies have been designed to accelerate sluggish kinetics but with limited results. Most of them promote the reaction by modulating the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, ignoring the synergistic effect of the reaction as a whole. Due to the introduction of gas, traditional liquid–solid two-phase reactions are no longer applicable to future research. Since gas-involved electrochemical reactions mostly occur at the junctions of gaseous reactants, liquid electrolytes and solid catalysts, the focus of future research on reaction kinetics should gradually shift to three-phase reaction interfaces. In this review, we briefly introduce the formation and constraints of the three-phase interface and propose three criteria to judge its merit, namely, the active site, mass diffusion and electron mass transfer. Subsequently, a series of modulation methods and relevant works are discussed in detail from the three improvement directions of ‘exposing more active sites, promoting mass diffusion and accelerating electron transfer’. Definitively, we provide farsighted insights into the understanding and research of three-phase interfaces in the future and point out the possible development direction of future regulatory methods, hoping that this review can broaden the future applications of the three-phase interface, including but not limited to gas-involved electrochemical reactions.
